questions.text: A 40-year-old male becomes breathless on lying down and can't sleep well. Which of the following is NOT a direct cause of his breathlessness?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

COPD Orthopnea is a common indicator of congestive heart failure (CHF), mechanical impairment of the diaphragm associated with obesity, or asthma triggered by esophageal reflux. Chronic persistent dyspnea is more typical of COPD , interstitial lung disease, and chronic thromboembolic disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Diaphragm mechanical function compromised on lying down. Option: B. Common cause - the accumulation of blood increases on lying down because gravitational aid goes nil. Option: C. Reflux increase on lying down.

questions.text: In the emphysematous patient with the following X-ray, Which is the best investigation to measure lung volume?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Body plethysmography The above x-ray shows a bullous lesion in an emphysematous patient . Body plethysmography is used to measure the volume of any gas containing space in the thorax including bullae . It is accurate in both obstructive and restrictive lung diseases . So it is the best investigation to measure the lung volume in an emphysematous patient with a bullous lesion as seen on an X-ray.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Inert gas dilution technique : It is used to measure the volume of regions that are well- This means they do not measure the trapped gas or bullae and are accurate in restrictive disease only. Option: B. Fractional exhaled NO is used as a noninvasive test in the diagnosis and monitoring of bronchial asthma . NO levels are increased in asthmatics and related to eosinophilic inflammation in the airways. Option: D. DLCO- the amount of CO diffusing per ml/mmHg/min gradien It is a measure of the diffusion capacity of the lungs. It doesn't measure the air trapped in bullae.

questions.text: A 64-year male is diagnosed with COPD with FEV1/FVC of 0.6 and FEV1 of 55% predicted. What is the severity as per GOLD guideline 2020?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Moderate Here FEV1 ≥50% but < 80% predicted: GOLD 2 Moderate

Highyeild:

CLASSIFICATION OF AIRFLOW LIMITATION SEVERITY IN COPD (BASED ON POST-BRONCHODILATOR FEV₁) In patients with FEV1/FVC < 0.70: GOLD 1 Mild FEV1 ≥ 80% predicted GOLD 2 Moderate 50% FEV1 < 80% predicted GOLD 3 Severe 30% FEV1 < 50% predicted GOLD 4 Very Severe FEV1 < 30% predicted COPD : chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; FEV1 : forced expiratory volume in 1 second; FVC : forced vital capacity; GOLD : Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease. Source: Reference 1. Reprinted with permission.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: FEV1/FVC < 0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted Option: C: FEV1/FVC < 0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but < 50% predicted Option: D: FEV1/FVC < 0.7 and FEV1 < 30% predicted.

questions.text: Which of the following emphysema is most commonly seen in cigarette smokers?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Centrilobular emphysema Centrilobular emphysema is the type most frequently associated with cigarette smoking . Centrilobular emphysema is usually most prominent in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes and is often quite focal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Panlobular emphysema is commonly observed in patients with α1AT deficiency, which has a predilection for the lower lobes. Option: C. It is commonly associated with significant airway inflammation and with centrilobular emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the following represents PiZ, the most common form of severe α1AT deficiency?

options.label: C
options.text: One Z and one null allele

questions.correct_answer: C. One Z and one null allele
questions.explanation:
Solution:

One Z and one null allele

Highyeild:

Individuals with two Z alleles or one Z and one null allele are referred to as PiZ , which is the most common form of severe α1AT deficiency. Option: A. The S allele, is associated with slightly reduced α1AT levels. Option: B. Rare individuals inherit null alleles, which lead to the absence of any α1AT production through a heterogeneous collection of mutations. M allele represents normal AT levels

questions.text: Which chromosome contains COPD susceptibility loci, a region near the HHIP gene?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chromosome 4

Highyeild:

GWAS have identified >20 regions of the genome that contain COPD susceptibility loci, including a region near the HHIP gene on chromosome 4, a cluster of genes on chromosome 15 ( including components of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and another gene, IREB2, related to mitochondrial iron regulation), and a region within a gene of unknown function (FAM13A) The nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and another gene, IREB2, are related to mitochondrial iron regulation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Chromosome 11 is related to the following diseases and disorders and some of those related to genes on chromosome 11: autism (NRXN2) acute intermittent porphyria. albinism. ataxia–telangiectasia. Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome beta- thalassemia. Option: C . Chromosome 15 is a focus of increasing interest in both psychiatry and neurology. Several neurodevelopmental disorders are genetically associated with this autosome, including Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome, Dyslexia, Autism, Hyperlexia, Ring 15 Chromosome syndrome, and Trisomy 15 syndrome. Option: D. Down syndrome occurs because of the extra copy of chromosome 21, which can cause the body and brain to develop differently than a child without the syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT seen in COPD?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clubbing Clubbing of the digits is not a sign of COPD, and its presence should alert the clinician to initiate an investigation for causes of clubbing. In this population, the development of lung cancer is the most likely explanation for newly developed clubbing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Patients may develop cyanosis, visible in the lips and nail beds. Option: C. Advanced disease may be accompanied by cachexia, with significant weight loss, bitemporal wasting, and diffuse loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue. Option: D. Signs of hyperinflation include a barrel chest and enlarged lung volumes with poor diaphragmatic excursion as assessed by percussion.

Exacerbation episodes It has been shown that a multifactorial index (BODE) i ncorporating airflow obstruction, exercise performance, dyspnea, and body mass index is a better predictor of mortality rate than pulmonary function alone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came in with hyperventilation (Carbon dioxide washout) associated with tetany. What is the cause of tetany seen in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Respiratory alkalosis In Hyperventilation- excess CO2 is released - less acid is in the blood- alkalosis occurs Hence to compensate for some protons released. Vacant space c reated on proteins (albumin) which were occupied by protons is now occupied by calcium ions. This decreased calcium ions in the blood leads to tetany.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is the current definitive test for establishing the presence and the pattern of emphysema?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chest CT Chest computed tomography (CT) scan is the current definitive test for establishing the presence or absence of emphysema , the pattern of emphysema, and the presence of significant disease involving medium and large airways.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Suggestive NOT definitive. Obvious bullae, paucity of parenchymal markings, or hyper lucency on chest x-ray suggest the presence of emphysema. Options: C, D. NOT preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following has NOT been demonstrated to improve the survival of patients with COPD?

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen therapy in chronically hypoxemic patients

options.label: D
options.text: Lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in selected patients with emphysema

questions.correct_answer: B. The use of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The use of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) There is suggestive, but not definitive, evidence that the use of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and muscarinic antagonists may reduce the mortality rate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C, D. Only three interventions — smoking cessation, oxygen therapy in chronically hypoxemic patients , and lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in selected patients with emphysema —have been demonstrated to improve the survival of patients with COPD.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic bronchitis Pneumothorax 1Causes:

Highyeild:

Often spontaneous (especially in tall young thin men) due to rupture of a subpleural bulla. Asthma; Emphysema TB; Staphylococcal pneumonia Lung abscess; Carcinoma; Cystic fibrosis Trauma Connective tissue disorders (Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) 2, Primary Spontaneous pneumothorax Features are No clinical evidence of pre-existing lung disease Rupture of apical subpleural blebs History of smoking Tall and thin individuals Young adults (10 to 30 years of age) Male gender 3. questions.text: A 69-year-old man with COPD has been admitted to the hospital 3 times over the past year for COPD exacerbation. He has a daily cough with sputum production and a predictive FEV1 of 45% predicted. He previously smoked a pack of cigarettes for 50 years, quitting 1 year ago. His saturation in room air is 91%. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the frequency of his exacerbation?

options.label: C
options.text: Nocturnal bipap with an inspiratory pressure of 18 cm H20 and expiratory pressure of 12 cm h20

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roflumilast 500 mcg daily Acute exacerbation of COPD is a frequent cause of mortality and morbidity in COPD. Most acute exacerbations are associated with airway inflammation or infection. Therefore strategies of prevention are primarily focused on decreasing inflammatory response and preventing infection. Selective PDE4 inhibitor ROFLUMILAST decrease exacerbation frequency in individuals with COPD. Azithromycin has both anti-inflammatory and antibiotic properties in an RCT it has been shown to decrease exacerbation frequency when administered at a dose of 500mg daily .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Other interventions to decrease exacerbation include the use of inhaled glucocorticoids, Long-acting anticholinergics and Long-acting beta-agonists Options B and C. O2 therapy and nocturnal ventilation are not indicated for the prevention of an exacerbation.

questions.text: The patient, 40 years old, with a history of smoking, presented in the emergency department with hemoptysis and it was estimated to be a blood loss of about 150 ml at a single expectoration. What will you do next?

options.label: B
options.text: Protect the airway and the non-bleeding lung

questions.correct_answer: B. Protect the airway and the non-bleeding lung
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protect the airway and the non-bleeding lung History of smoking and massive hemoptysis most commonly suggests a In the case of massive hemoptysis, the first and foremost goal is to protect the airway and non-bleeding lungs because asphyxiation can happen quickly.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Endotracheal intubation Endotracheal intubation is avoided unless truly necessary because suctioning through an et tube is a less effective means of removing blood and clot than the cough reflex Option:C. Angiography Angiography is done for both therapeutic and diagnostic capabilities and can also help by localizing local extravasation. But protecting the airway is of paramount importance. Option:D. Flexible bronchoscopy This can be used to locate the size of the bleeding but it has only a 50% chance of locating the site and experts do not agree on the timing of bronchoscopy especially in the time of massive hemoptysis

questions.text: Patient, 40 years of age, taking anti-tubercular drugs for the past 3 months has been given a positive sputum sample and the patient’s clinical condition is deteriorating rapidly. What is to be done next?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform molecular testing for the anti-tubercular drugs that the patient is taking

options.label: C
options.text: Add one or more drugs to the failing regimen

options.label: D
options.text: Stop the current regimen as soon as possible

questions.correct_answer: C. Add one or more drugs to the failing regimen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Add one or more drugs to the failing regimen A positive sputum sample after three months of anti-tubercular drug therapy suggests a failing regimen . Add one or more drugs to the failing regimen. This is the cardinal rule when the patient’s condition is worsening . There is no point in waiting for the results of retesting when there is a possibility of improving the patient's current condition by adding one or two drugs to the current regimen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. perform molecular testing for the anti-tubercular drugs that the patient is taking. Molecular testing is the step to approach the treatment by identifying the initial susceptibility of resistance to at least rifampicin and or isoniazid . These results will take some time as the patient's clinical condition is worsening; this is not an option. Option: B. retest the sputum culture retesting the sputum culture will take time and since the patient’s clinical condition is worsening, this is not an option Option: D. Stop the current regimen as soon as possible there is no point in stopping the regimen as the patient’s worsened condition is because of the pathogen and its effects and is not because of the drug per se.
